br.usp.poli.takiyama.common
Class InequalityConstraint

java.lang.Object
  br.usp.poli.takiyama.common.InequalityConstraint
All Implemented Interfaces:
Constraint, Replaceable<Constraint>
public final class InequalityConstraint
extends java.lang.Object

This class represents inequality constraints of the form X ≠ Y, where X and Y are a Terms.

Inequalities with two constants, like t ≠ q, are invalid. If a method detects a invalid constraint, it returns null.

Author:
Felipe Takiyama

    apply

    public Constraint apply(Substitution s)
                 throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException,
                        java.lang.IllegalStateException
    Description copied from interface: Constraint
    Applies the substitution in this constraint.

    If the resulting constraint is always false (for instance, q ≠ q), then throws an IllegalArgumentException.

    If the specified substitution does not apply to this constraint, then returns this constraint unchanged.

    Parameters:
    s - The substitution to apply on the constraint
    Returns:
    The constraint that results from the application of the specified substitution to this constraint, following the rules specified above.
    Throws:
    java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the resulting constraint is always false
    java.lang.IllegalStateException - If the resulting constraint involves only constants

    isConsistentWith

    public boolean isConsistentWith(Binding b)
    Description copied from interface: Constraint
    Returns true if the specified Binding satisfies this constraint. In other words, returns true if applying the specified binding to this constraint results in a valid sentence.

    This method also returns false when it is not possible to evaluate whether the resulting constraint is valid or not.

    For instance, let X, Y, W and Z be logical variables with D(X) = D(Y) = D(W) = D(Z) = {a, b,..., z}. Then:

  • X != a is consistent with X/b (because b != a is true)
  • X != Y is consistent with W/Z (because X != Y is still true)
  • X != a is not consistent with X/a (because a != a is not true)
  • X != a is not consistent with X/W (because W != a is not necessarily true)
  • X != Y is not consistent with X/W (because W != Y is not necessarily true)
  • X == Y is consistent with W/Z (because X == Y is still true)
  • X == a is consistent with X/a (because a == a is true)
  • X == a is consistent with X/W (because X = a & X = W implies W = a)
  • X == Y is consistent with X/W (because X = Y & X = W implies W = Y)
  • X == a is not consistent with X/b (because b == a is not true)

    Parameters:
    b - The binding to test
    Returns:
    true if this constraint is consistent with the specified binding, false otherwise.

    applySubstitution

    public Constraint applySubstitution(Binding substitution)
    Deprecated. Apply the substitution in this inequality. The following rules apply:
  • X ≠ Y and X/q returns Y ≠ q
  • X ≠ Y and Y/q returns X ≠ q
  • X ≠ Y and X/W returns W ≠ Y
  • X ≠ Y and Y/W returns X ≠ W
  • X ≠ t and X/q returns null
  • X ≠ t and Y/q returns X ≠ t
  • X ≠ t and X/W returns W ≠ t
  • X ≠ t and Y/W returns X ≠ t

    Parameters:
    substitution - The substitution to apply on the constraint
    Returns:
    The constraint that results from the application of the specified substitution to this constraint, following the rules specified above.

    toBinding

    public Binding toBinding()
                  throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
    Description copied from interface: Constraint
    Returns the Binding corresponding to this constraint. That is, if this constraint is t1 ≠ t2, then this method returns the binding t1/t2.

    Specified by:
    toBinding in interface Constraint
    Returns:
    The Binding corresponding to this constraint.
    Throws:
    java.lang.IllegalStateException

    toInverseBinding

    public Binding toInverseBinding()
                         throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
    Description copied from interface: Constraint
    Returns the Binding obtained by inverting the terms of this constraint. That is, if this constraint is t2 ≠ t2, then this method returns the binding t2/t1.

    Specified by:
    toInverseBinding in interface Constraint
    Returns:
    The inverse binding corresponding to this constraint.
    Throws:
    java.lang.IllegalStateException

    logicalVariables

    public java.util.Set<LogicalVariable> logicalVariables()
